Chat with an OpenAI model

Source: R/provider-openai.R
chat_openai.Rd

OpenAI provides a number of chat-based models, mostly under the ChatGPT brand. Note that a ChatGPT Plus membership does not grant access to the API. You will need to sign up for a developer account (and pay for it) at the developer platform.

Usage

chat_openai(
  system_prompt = NULL,
  base_url = "https://api.openai.com/v1",
  api_key = openai_key(),
  model = NULL,
  params = NULL,
  seed = deprecated(),
  api_args = list(),
  echo = c("none", "output", "all")
)

Arguments

system_prompt

A system prompt to set the behavior of the assistant.

base_url

The base URL to the endpoint; the default uses OpenAI.

api_key

API key to use for authentication.

You generally should not supply this directly, but instead set the OPENAI_API_KEY environment variable. The best place to set this is in .Renviron, which you can easily edit by calling usethis::edit_r_environ().

model

The model to use for the chat. The default, NULL, will pick a reasonable default, and tell you about. We strongly recommend explicitly choosing a model for all but the most casual use.

params

Common model parameters, usually created by params().

seed

Optional integer seed that ChatGPT uses to try and make output more reproducible.

api_args

Named list of arbitrary extra arguments appended to the body of every chat API call. Combined with the body object generated by ellmer with modifyList().

echo

One of the following options:

  • none: don't emit any output (default when running in a function).

  • text: echo text output as it streams in (default when running at the console).

  • all: echo all input and output.

Note this only affects the chat() method.

Value

A Chat object.

See also

Other chatbots: chat_anthropic(), chat_aws_bedrock(), chat_azure_openai(), chat_cortex_analyst(), chat_databricks(), chat_deepseek(), chat_github(), chat_google_gemini(), chat_groq(), chat_mistral(), chat_ollama(), chat_openrouter(), chat_perplexity()

Examples

chat <- chat_openai()
#> Using model = "gpt-4o".
chat$chat("
  What is the difference between a tibble and a data frame?
  Answer with a bulleted list
")
#> - **Printing**:
#>   - **Tibble**: Provides a more reader-friendly print method, 
#> displaying only the first 10 rows and as many columns as can fit on 
#> the screen. It dynamically adjusts to the size of the console, showing
#> variable names and their data types.
#>   - **Data Frame**: Prints all rows and columns, which can clutter the
#> console for large datasets.
#> 
#> - **Column Types**:
#>   - **Tibble**: Always maintains the original data types and does not 
#> change them unexpectedly when subsetting.
#>   - **Data Frame**: May coerce data types under certain conditions, 
#> for example converting strings to factors by default (though this 
#> behavior may vary depending on the version of R).
#> 
#> - **Subsetting**:
#>   - **Tibble**: Always returns a tibble when subsetting, and 
#> subsetting a single column with `$` or `[` always results in a vector.
#>   - **Data Frame**: Subsetting may result in different formats; 
#> extracting a single row or column can return a vector or a smaller 
#> data frame, depending on the subsetting method used.
#> 
#> - **Column Names**:
#>   - **Tibble**: Allows non-syntactic column names (e.g., names with 
#> spaces or starting with a number) without any issues.
#>   - **Data Frame**: Generally expects syntactic names, though 
#> non-standard names can be used but with caution to avoid errors.
#> 
#> - **Creation**:
#>   - **Tibble**: Created using the `tibble()` or `tibble::tibble()` 
#> functions, offering a variety of convenient features for initializing 
#> columns with specific types.
#>   - **Data Frame**: Created using the `data.frame()` function, which 
#> may automatically convert strings to factors unless specified 
#> otherwise.
#> 
#> - **Performance**:
#>   - **Tibble**: Designed with large datasets in mind, potentially 
#> offering better performance in terms of both speed and memory usage.
#>   - **Data Frame**: Well-optimized for general use but may not handle 
#> the same large-scale operations as efficiently as tibbles.
#> 
#> - **Error Messaging**:
#>   - **Tibble**: Generally provides more informative error messages 
#> that can aid in debugging.
#>   - **Data Frame**: Error messages can be less descriptive, 
#> potentially making it more challenging to troubleshoot issues.
#> 
#> These differences make tibbles preferred in tidyverse packages for 
#> their consistency and user-friendly design, especially when working 
#> with larger datasets.

chat$chat("Tell me three funny jokes about statisticians")
#> Sure, here are three light-hearted jokes about statisticians:
#> 
#> 1. **Mean Joke**: Why don't statisticians trust lakes?
#>    - Because they know all the means are not on the level!
#> 
#> 2. **Marathon Joke**: Why did the statistician bring a ladder to the 
#> bar?
#>    - Because he heard the drinks were on the house and he wanted to 
#> test the distribution!
#> 
#> 3. **Dating Joke**: Why was the statistician always single?
#>    - Because he thought all the good relationships were taken or 
#> independent events!
#> 
#> I hope these brought a smile to your face!
